response:
Based on a bit of backward‐induction reasoning—and accounting for the fact that as rounds progress your money loses value 10% per round while mine loses 5% per round—the subgame‐perfect solution suggests the following equilibrium outcome if I (Alice) propose in round 1:

• If you (Bob) reject my round‑1 offer, then in round 2 you’ll have the chance to propose a division. In doing so you can guarantee yourself effectively about 0.95×[10,000 minus 0.9×(what I’d get in round 3)], which ends up giving you roughly 6,551.72 dollars in “present‐value” terms.  
• To get you to accept right away, I need to offer you at least what you’d expect by waiting. Solving the indifference equation—
  Alice’s share = 10,000 – 0.95×[10,000 – 0.9×(Alice’s share)]
—we get that my own share would be about 3,448.28 dollars and yours about 6,551.72 dollars.

Thus, my round‑1 proposal is to divide $10,000 as follows:

{"alice_gain": 3448.28, "bob_gain": 6551.72}

I’m open to discussing any details, but that’s my formal offer.
